qas.question: How much effort did France put into wars to defend its colonies?

answers.text: It would let colonies defend themselves or would offer only minimal help

qas.question: Identify a major factor in this feckless strategy by France of not defending its colonies with enthusiasm?

answers.text: geography, coupled with the superiority of the British navy, made it difficult

qas.question: Why did the French rulers need a large domestic army?

answers.text: several long land borders made an effective domestic army imperative

qas.question: In treaty negotiations, what trades did France hope to make.

answers.text: in treaty negotiations, to trade territorial acquisitions in Europe to regain lost overseas possessions.

qas.question: How much success did France have in adding European territory with this approach?

answers.text: France had few counterbalancing European successes.

context: For much of the eighteenth century, France approached its wars in the same way. <a0_0>It would let colonies defend themselves or would offer only minimal help<a0_0/> (sending them limited numbers of troops or inexperienced soldiers), anticipating that fights for the colonies would most likely be lost anyway. This strategy was to a degree forced upon France: <a1_0>geography, coupled with the superiority of the British navy, made it difficult<a1_0/> for the French navy to provide significant supplies and support to French colonies. Similarly, <a2_0>several long land borders made an effective domestic army imperative<a2_0/> for any French ruler. Given these military necessities, the French government, unsurprisingly, based its strategy overwhelmingly on the army in Europe: it would keep most of its army on the continent, hoping for victories closer to home. The plan was to fight to the end of hostilities and then, <a3_0>in treaty negotiations, to trade territorial acquisitions in Europe to regain lost overseas possessions.<a3_0/> This approach did not serve France well in the war, as the colonies were indeed lost, but although much of the European war went well, by its end <a4_0>France had few counterbalancing European successes.
